Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900) was a German philosopher and one of the founders of what came to be known as the existentialist movement. He believed, in essence, that mankind should concentrate on the here and now as opposed to the hereafter. I don't buy into everything that he had to say, but I find some of his stuff rather interesting, at least in terms of discussion. 
 
 "Sins" are indispensable to every society organized on an ecclesiastical basis; they are the only reliable weapons of power; the priest lives upon sins; it is necessary to him that there be "sinning."
 
 "Faith" means the will to avoid knowing what is true.
 
 Christianity came into existence in order to lighten the heart; but now it has first to burden the heart so as afterwards to be able to lighten it.
 
 Christianity has done its utmost to close the circle and declared even doubt to be sin. One is supposed to be cast into belief without reason, by a miracle, and from then on to swim in it as in the brightest and least ambiguous of elements: even a glance towards land, even the thought that one perhaps exists for something else as well as swimming, even the slightest impulse of our amphibious nature -- is sin! And notice that all this means that the foundation of belief and all reflection on its origin is likewise excluded as sinful. What is wanted are blindness and intoxication and an eternal song over the waves in which reason has drowned.
 
 The Christian church is an encyclopaedia of prehistoric cults and conceptions of the most diverse origin, and that is why it is so capable of proselytizing: it always could, and it can still go wherever it pleases and it always found, and always finds something similar to itself to which it can adapt itself and gradually impose upon it a Christian meaning.
 
 On Paul...
 
 That the ship of Christianity threw overboard a good deal of its Jewish ballast, that it went, and was able to go, among the pagans--that was due to this one man, a very tortured, very pitiful, very unpleasant man, unpleasant even to himself. He suffered from a fixed idea--or more precisely, from a fixed, ever-present, never-resting question: what about the Jewish law? and particularly the fulfillment of this law? In his youth he had himself wanted to satisfy it, with a ravenous hunger for this highest distinction which the Jews could conceive - this people who were propelled higher than any other people by the imagination of the ethically sublime, and who alone succeeded in creating a holy god together with the idea of sin as a transgression against this holiness. Paul became the fanatical defender of this god and his law and guardian of his honor; at the same time, in the struggle against the transgressors and doubters, lying in wait for them, he became increasingly harsh and evilly disposed towards them, and inclined towards the most extreme punishments. And now he found that--hot-headed, sensual, melancholy, malignant in his hatred as he was-- he was himself unable to fulfill the law; indeed, and this seemed strangest to him, his extravagant lust to domineer provoked him continually to transgress the law, and he had to yield to this thorn.
 
 Is it really his "carnal nature" that makes him transgress again and again? And not rather, as he himself suspected later, behind it the law itself, which must constantly prove itself unfulfillable and which lures him to transgression with irresistable charm? But at that time he did not yet have this way out. He had much on his conscience - he hints at hostility, murder, magic, idolatry, lewdness, drunkenness, and pleasure in dissolute carousing - and... moments came when he said to himself:"It is all in vain; the torture of the unfulfilled law cannot be overcome."... The law was the cross to which he felt himself nailed: how he hated it! how he searched for some means to annihilate it--not to fulfill it any more himself!
 
 And finally the saving thought struck him,... "It is unreasonable to persecute this Jesus! Here after all is the way out; here is the perfect revenge; here and nowhere else I have and hold the annihilator of the law!"... Until then the ignominious death had seemed to him the chief argument against the Messianic claim of which the new doctrine spoke: but what if it were necessary to get rid of the law?
 
 The tremendous consequences of this idea, of this solution of the riddle, spin before his eyes; at one stroke he becomes the happiest man; the destiny of the Jews--no, of all men--seems to him to be tied to this idea, to this second of its sudden illumination; he has the thought of thoughts, the key of keys, the light of lights; it is around him that all history must revolve henceforth. For he is from now on the teacher of the annihilation of the law...
 
 This is the first Christian, the inventor of Christianity.

Having read only one of Nietzsche's tomes, 'Thus Spoke Zarathustra', I'm hardly qualified to give lessons on his philosophy. (Perhaps others have read what translates as 'The Gay Science' : an intriguing title). 
 
 But I think what Nietzsche has to say about Christianity must be understood as ironic and multi-layered. His criticism of the moral climate of the 19th century seems remote (at least to me) from our modern meditations on the evils of 'consumer societies' etc. 
 
 At the basis of his anti-Christian or anti-religious views is the idea that human nature is driven by 'a will to power', and that 'resentment' occurs as a result of this drive being frustrated in action. Among the causes of this frustration or corruption of human nature, are religions, such as Christianity, that feed on resentment. 
 
 Some specially gifted human beings rise above this frustration/resentment that religion inculcates or encourages - these are the 'supermen' which continue to provoke so many false notions and clichés

I never actually read Nietsche, I never had the time to. Reading serious books requires both more time and uninterrupted attention than the regular reading.
 
 However, even from reading about Nietsche, and from excerpts, I know enough to know just how wrong the superficial reading by Easyrider & co comes out. "God is dead", as actually used by Nietsche is far closer to Easyrider's position than he realizes. Hah, just one sentence further, we can see that things are far more complicated. 
 
God is dead. God remains dead. And we have killed him. How shall we, murderers of all murderers, console ourselves?

 
 Since Wiki is handy, this paragraph, with added bolds by me, should illustrate what is the real meaning of the phrase:
 
 
Nietzsche is also well-known for the statement "God is dead". While in popular belief it is Nietzsche himself who blatantly made this declaration, it was actually placed into the mouth of a character, a "madman," in The Gay Science. It was also later proclaimed by Nietzsche's Zarathustra. This largely misunderstood statement does not proclaim a physical death, but a natural end to the belief in God being the foundation of the western mind. It is also widely misunderstood as a kind of gloating declaration, when it is actually described as a tragic lament by the character Zarathustra.
 
 "God is Dead" is more of an observation than a declaration. Nietzsche did not advance arguments for atheism, but merely observed that, for all practical purposes, his contemporaries lived "as if" God were dead. Nietzsche believed this "death" would eventually undermine the foundations of morality and lead to moral relativism and moral nihilism. To avoid this, he believed in re-evaluating the foundations of morality and placing them not on a pre-determined, but a natural foundation through comparative analysis.

 
 What Nietsche is trying to get across is that our knowledge, our science has gone beyond the dogma of the middle ages and with knowledge driven god from the ultimate omnipresence that is the heart of christian monotheism. The moment when we discovered that lightning is created by air friction, thunder stopped being the angry shout of god. The moment we knew that eclipses happened regularly, predictably and were harmless, we ceased to fear god would take the sun away. Knowing more and more of nature, we find it more and more difficult to believe in god. And thus, god leaves our minds.
 
 And this leaves a vacuum. Nietsche observed and pointed out that god was woven into the very fabric of our society, and that removing him leaves the basic structure of our morality and ethics significantly weakened. Without foundation. To Nietsche, this would necessitate the establishment of a new set of values, ones that would hold without a god to support them.

I think there is a tendency to 'typecast' Nietzsche as a philosophical villain, a 'proto-Nazi', and so on. His idea of the 'superman' has unfortunate connotations in modern times.
 
 But the 'superman' is meant be an 'archetype' - a powerful and self-directed human being who has mastered his own passionate nature, and can rise above the 'primitive' moral limitations that are imposed on the common herd by religious beliefs.

 It's complex: the people who are told are not the religious (at first), but cynical atheists. We can't see it as clearly good or bad: it's simply too immense for current man to know:
 
 "How shall we comfort ourselves, the murderers of all murderers?
 What was holiest and mightiest of all that the world has yet owned has bled
 to death under our knives: who will wipe this blood off us?
 What water is there for us to clean ourselves?
 What festivals of atonement, what sacred gamesshall we have to invent?
 Is not the greatness of this deed too great for us?
 Must we ourselves not become gods simply to appear worthy of it?
 There has never been a greater deed; and whoever is born after us -
 For the sake of this deed he will belong to a higher history than all
 history hitherto."

Nietzsche comes across as sympathetic to Jesus the man. He views Jesus as a rebel, almost an anarchist, who fought against the religious institution of his day. But he has little or nothing good to say about the Christianity which later emerged, whether from an ideological or institutional perspective. He appears to view the Christianity of his time as a hindrance to social and intellectual development. To paraphrase one of his remarks, "Jesus was the only Christian who ever lived". And in that regard, some of what Nietzsche says resonates with me. IMO, the message of Jesus was obscured and corrupted as early as the mid-to-late 1st century, when he was deified and transformed from an iconoclast into an object of worship.

Perhaps it's impertinent to continue this thread, but suppose we focused on Nietzsche's infamous declaration that God is dead. Would anyone be interested in airing their opinions? I'm going to assume that a few people might respond, and make some tentative opening remarks. 
 
 I think Orion has already implied, in his observations, that this obituary is not meant to be understood literally. According to Nietzsche, God was never alive. So the death of God is a metaphor that 'stands for' the moral situation which has evolved in Western civilisation as a consequence of the scientific and intellectual revolutions of the Enlightenment. 
 
 In other words, the Judeo-Christian moral consensus that expressed the highest ideals of Western humanity has been superseded by the Age of Science. The divine authority upon which Christian morality is founded has been rejected. And it is now claimed that all values, including religious values, are created by man.
 
 On this view, religion is a delusion - at best a mere comfort blanket that humanity wraps around itself to protect it from the bleak indifference of a Godless universe. The spiritual dimension in human nature is denied, and guidance that human beings once sought in religious beliefs is now provided by rational inquiry.
 
 It may be that in abandoning religious faith and erecting Science as our 'god', we are merely exchanging one belief system for another that is no more trustworthy or ultimately justifiable. 
 
 I don't think we need to refer to Zarathustra as a kind of Holy Writ in order to discuss what seems to flow from the proposition that "God is dead". Though if this discussion should take off, we may need to consider some auxiliary ideas - such as the advent of the übermensch or 'superman'.
You're thinking in the right direction. There's more to what Nietsche said. That's what we tried to explain to Easy, but he just closed his mind...

 1) Biblical literalism of various degrees
 2) Biblical innerancy
 3) Conservative political beliefs
 4) Support of authority
 5) A sense of seperation from society at large
 6) Considering one's faith by far the most important thing
 7) A certain aggression to and ignorance of other religions and positions.

It seems to say that anyone who believes will live forever (even the demons who are said to believe and tremble), and that those who do not believe 'shall not have life' rather than 'shall have life in Hell'. Seems resurrection-focused to me.

Have you not heard of that madman who lit a lantern in the bright morning
 hours,
 ran to the market place, and cried incessantly:
 "I seek God! I seek God!"
 As many of those who did not believe in God
 were standing around just then,
 he provoked much laughter.
 Has he got lost? asked one.
 Did he lose his way like a child? asked another.
 Or is he hiding?
 Is he afraid of us? Has he gone on a voyage? emigrated?
 Thus they yelled and laughed.
 
 The madman jumped into their midst and pierced them with his eyes.
 "Whither is God?" he cried; "I will tell you.
 We have killed him---you and I.
 All of us are his murderers.
 But how did we do this?
 How could we drink up the sea?
 Who gave us the sponge to wipe away the entire horizon?
 What were we doing when we unchained this earth from its sun?
 Whither is it moving now? Whither are we moving?
 Away from all suns?
 Are we not plunging continually?
 Backward, sideward, forward, in all directions?
 Is there still any up or down?
 Are we not straying, as through an infinite nothing?
 Do we not feel the breath of empty space?
 Has it not become colder? Is not night continually closing in on us?
 Do we not need to light lanterns in the morning?
 Do we hear nothing as yet of the noise of the gravediggers
 who are burying God?
 Do we smell nothing as yet of the divine decomposition?
 Gods, too, decompose.
 God is dead.
 God remains dead.
 And we have killed him.
 
 "How shall we comfort ourselves, the murderers of all murderers?
 What was holiest and mightiest of all that the world has yet owned has bled
 to death under our knives: who will wipe this blood off us?
 What water is there for us to clean ourselves?
 What festivals of atonement, what sacred gamesshall we have to invent?
 Is not the greatness of this deed too great for us?
 Must we ourselves not become gods simply to appear worthy of it?
 There has never been a greater deed; and whoever is born after us -
 For the sake of this deed he will belong to a higher history than all
 history hitherto."
 
 Here the madman fell silent and looked again at his listeners;
 and they, too, were silent and stared at him in astonishment.
 At last he threw his lantern on the ground,
 and it broke into pieces and went out.
 "I have come too early," he said then; "my time is not yet.
 This tremendous event is still on its way, still wandering;
 it has not yet reached the ears of men.
 Lightning and thunder require time;
 the light of the stars requires time;
 deeds, though done, still require time to be seen and heard.
 This deed is still more distant from them than most distant stars -
 and yet they have done it themselves.
 
 It has been related further that on the same day
 the madman forced his way into several churches
 and there struck up his requiem aeternam deo.
 Led out and called to account, he is said always to have replied nothing
 but:
 "What after all are these churches now
 if they are not the tombs and sepulchers of God?"

I think Orion has already implied, in his observations, that this obituary is not meant to be understood literally. According to Nietzsche, God was never alive. So the death of God is a metaphor that 'stands for' the moral situation which has evolved in Western civilisation as a consequence of the scientific and intellectual revolutions of the Enlightenment.
I would support this. Nietzsche seems unconcerned or dismissive of a metaphysically existent God: his focus is on the gods that people believe in. I don't know if he ever really tried to disprove the metaphysical God's existence. As he often calls himself a psychologist, and attacks system-builders like Kant I suspect it was a statement about culture and belief, not a seperate God. 
 
 
In other words, the Judeo-Christian moral consensus that expressed the highest ideals of Western humanity has been superseded by the Age of Science. The divine authority upon which Christian morality is founded has been rejected. And it is now claimed that all values, including religious values, are created by man.
Yes: and this is the cause of the terrible sense of both weight and being in a vacuum, in verses 3 and 2 respectively. It's a rather typical existentialist sense of having to face the world alone.
 
 
On this view, religion is a delusion - at best a mere comfort blanket that humanity wraps around itself to protect it from the bleak indifference of a Godless universe. The spiritual dimension in human nature is denied, and guidance that human beings once sought in religious beliefs is now provided by rational inquiry.
Hmmm: I don't know if Nietzsche rejected the spiritual. He seems in favour of earlier gods, and I'm not sure if he dismisses religion entirely. It seems more that religion in his own time had been made corrupt and enfeebled. A euthanasia of God perhaps (Pullman has something like this)
 
 
It may be that in abandoning religious faith and erecting Science as our 'god', we are merely exchanging one belief system for another that is no more trustworthy or ultimately justifiable.
Possibly, although Nietzsche seems very supportive of science

But the risk of fundamentalism is over-attatchment to a single position.

 
 I'd say there is zero risk as long as you had the correct position, as in Christ as one's Lord and Savior. The real risk is being non-attached to Christ while one's salvation slowly ticks away with each breath.
 
 
There is also the issue of the reliability of the Bible.

 
 The preponderance of the evidence concerning Christ's salvation for man in the New Testament is overwhelming. Some people want to nit pick and can't see the forest for the trees.
 
 
Secondly, it's always good to understand the opponent.

 
 I think Orion's anti-Biblical Christianity stance is well documented, if one will simply review his posts. His bringing a Nietzsche or a liberal Bishop Spong, etc., into the fray time after time, instead of a Billy Graham or anyone who supports the Biblical Christ, only magnifies his agenda.

I think Orion has already implied, in his observations, that this obituary is not meant to be understood literally. According to Nietzsche, God was never alive. So the death of God is a metaphor that 'stands for' the moral situation which has evolved in Western civilisation as a consequence of the scientific and intellectual revolutions of the Enlightenment.

 
 
I would support this. Nietzsche seems unconcerned or dismissive of a metaphysically existent God: his focus is on the gods that people believe in. I don't know if he ever really tried to disprove the metaphysical God's existence. As he often calls himself a psychologist, and attacks system-builders like Kant I suspect it was a statement about culture and belief, not a seperate God.
 
 
 My interpretation of Nietzsche suggests to me that he was proclaiming the death (i.e., irrelevance) of the traditional god of Judeo-Christian origin. This was a god to whom people offered intercessory prayers in the hope that such entreaty would convince this divine being to effect some favourable outcome in their lives. You can find this concept carried over to this day, especially if you visit a religion forum which has a thread titled "Prayer Requests". Personally, I prefer the concept of a God who is not particularly interested in what you want but is more interested in what you need, and who knows what you need even before you do.
 
 It was also a god who was created by and assigned attributes by man. As expected, this god was quite anthropomorphic. The religious philosopher Paul Tillich, however, suggests that God cannot be justifiably defined to such an extent. Rather, Tillich refers to God as the "ineffable ground of all being", defying expression or description. A rather nebulous characterization, but I think that was Tillich's point. It's generally agreed that Tillich's thinking appears to have been somewhat influenced by Nietzsche. 
 
 So, at the risk of putting words in Nietzsche's mouth, if this traditional god cannot, in fact, be defined, and if it does not intervene in the lives of men as a result of prayer requests, then such god is for all practical purposes irrelevant ("dead"). It's been awhile since I read him, but I don't know how far Nietzsche went with this. I rather doubt that he was an atheist, given that (I think) the existence or non-existence of a divine being would probably not have interested him.

My interpretation of Nietzsche suggests to me that he was proclaiming the death (i.e., irrelevance) of the traditional god of Judeo-Christian origin.

@ Orion and Obvious Child.
 
 I think it's reasonable to suppose that Zarathustra is Nietzsche's mouthpiece - a prophet who proclaims a message that has a rhetorical appeal in the moral (or amoral) universe in which we now find ourselves. 
 
 What I'm getting at here is some of the prevailing ideas in Western civilisation have jumped into the moral vacuum left by what Nietzsche called the 'death of god'.
 
 For example: 
 
 The idea that a crucial purpose of life is to find your 'true self', and being faithful to it is the highest virtue.
 
 The insistence that moral and aesthetic values are shaped by cultural pressures, and as society changes so values must change. Since we are the creators of our own values, which need not be shared, we are also responsible for living up to them.
 
 A scepticism about truth and fact - which leads to a plurality of interpretations that are completely at odds with the consensus and settled authority of a religious age.
 
 The claim that knowledge and strength are more valuable than compassion and meekness. 
 
 Lots more 'modern instances' like these can be inferred from the sayings of Nietzsche/Zarathustra which seem to anticipate the moral ethos of our times
 
 The reason this thread interests me is because the insights of Nietzsche challenge us to deal with the moral consequences of living in a world without God. Which leads me to suggest that Easyrider's reactions to this thinker are too precipitate and defensive. People who do not share his religious convictions may share his moral concerns.
 
 I am, of course, troubled by some of Nietzsche's weird ideas - a few of which seem to teeter on the border of irrationalism. His portentous style of writing can also be a turn off - often hilarious, as OC observes, but unintentionally so. (I might be wrong about his style: I have been told that my copy of Zarathustra is a rotten translation).

 The Anvil that Has Worn Out Many Hammers
 
 Nineteenth century writer H.L. Hastings once forcibly illustrated the unique way in which the Bible has withstood the attacks of skepticism: 
 
 "Infidels of eighteen hundred years have been refuting and overthrowing this book, and yet it stands today as solid rock. Its circulation increases, and it is more loved and cherished and read today than ever before. Infidels, with all their assaults, make about as much impression on this book as a man with a tack hammer would on the Pyramids of Egypt. 
 
 "When the French monarch proposed the persecution of Christians in his dominion, an old statesman and warrior said to him, 'Sire, the church of God is an anvil that has worn out many hammers.' So the hammers of infidels have been pecking away at this book for ages, but the hammers are worn out, and the anvil still endures. If this book had not been the book of God, men would have destroyed it long ago. Emperors and popes, kings and priests, princes and rulers have all tried their hand at it; they die and the book still lives."
 
 "No other book has been so chopped, knived, sifted, scrutinized, and vilified. What book on philosophy or religion or psychology or belles lettres of classical or modern times has been subject to such a mass attack as the Bible? With such venom and skepticism? In Reform Judaism, if there is an afterlife, it's supposedly based on rewarding works - believing in God is not even necessary. This is somewhat humerous since who is it that's supposedly going to reward those works if God doesn't exist? It's also embarrassing for the movement that it can't define what kind of works, or how many works, it takes to gain eternal life, and thus no one can have any peace of mind during this lifetime wondering if they're ever going to make it or not. To make matters worse, as noted in the beliefs section I previously posted, Reform Judaism states that "Most believe God is forgiving of all." Again, one has to wonder then if Reform Jews will feel at ease in eternity with Adolph Hitler and Joseph Stalin and other serial murderers running loose in their midst? Have you no answer for that??? And not the least of your problems is that there's absolutely no objective foundation that any of these beliefs are either credible or ordained by God. And this is the platform you're going to use to step off into eternity? Quite frankly, even the Easter Bunny or Santa Claus fares as well as these stretches of the imagination. I strongly urge you to get into something else, or provide some credible evidence that what you currently have is worthy of embracing.
